<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMem2BinFile:
```c
bool UtMem2BinFile(const void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE *fp;

    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "w")))
    {
        fwrite(Memory, Length, 1, fp);
        fclose(fp);
        return true;
    }
    else
    {
        printf("UtMem2BinFile: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
        UtAssert_True(false, "UtMem2BinFile: Error Opening File");
        return false;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UtMem2BinFile:
#define UtAssert_True(Expression, __VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(Expression,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
fclose(fp);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment calls the C standard library function fclose(fp). fclose does not call UtMem2BinFile (directly or indirectly), and there is no indication in the provided code that fclose has been redefined to invoke UtMem2BinFile. The UtAssert_True macro (shown in the additional code) appears only in the error path, not in the path containing fclose, and it expands to UtAssertEx/UtAssert_GetContext which do not call UtMem2BinFile. Therefore no direct or indirect self-call occurs.
